quote: Ten minutes into the USA Gravel National Championships, I watched Chase Wark attack up the left side of a Minnesota highway. It was a doomed move, I thought, going into the early breakaway on a 98-mile course with over 7,000 feet of climbing...

I pushed 471w (6.7w/kg) for five minutes and nearly got dropped. But I dug deep over the top of the climb, wheezing and suffering, but still in the main group. I looked back to see the damage that had been done, expecting to see 10-15 riders left...
I was dropped with two and a half hours to go. From the moment I was dropped, I pushed 293w (NP 323w) for 50 miles and still lost 13 minutes to the lead group â€“ that's how fast they were going.
It was an interesting race. It didn't start out too hard, a break had about four minutes, and then it just kind of turned into survival on the final climbs.

The race was the hardest one we've had so far. Every climb, the group would splinter and kind of have a selection. Finally, at the southern end of the course, we were a selection of six or seven riders.

I was one of the early victims [in the mass pileup at mile 27] and became a landing pad for other riders and their bikes. All told maybe 20 went down, and half wouldn't continue on. Luckily landing in dirt isn't as bad a pavement and I was miraculously ok.

It stings to put time, money, and energy into a race only to leave before I was even tired or hungry. My string of bad luck in races all summer long continues, something I'm really frustrated with. I'm just pining for a clean run.
Amid the ongoing 'big tyre' debate in gravel, Minnesota favoured setups closer to 40mm rather than the 2.2-inch widths common at Unbound, Big Sugar or Mid South.

Instead of rolling into town for a simple sprint finish, we turned left into Stoney Point Park on the edge of La Crescent. The first part of the climb was everything you would expect: 11% of gravel, a little chunky, but nothing too bad. But then, your eyes gaze up at the road in front of you...
Riders will wind their way through hardwood forests, farm fields, trout stream valleys, and ridge-top gravel roads... What defines all these routes is their relentlessness.

And then, something happened that I was completely unprepared for. We turned right into the town of Eitzen, and there was the aid station, a paved downhill at 35 mph. Brennan Wertz attacked through the aid station because 500 meters later, there was a super technical gravel descent.
I got dropped on most of the gravel descents

The championship coincides with La Crescent's Apple Fest, a long-standing local celebration that includes a parade, carnival rides, and a 5K. While it may make the town busier, it also means extra activities for families who come along to spectate.

$60,000 prize purse ($30k male/female)! My jaw dropped, USAC had never had prize money at any road or mountain bike nationals, the only thing on the line was a patriotic jersey. This was the biggest single day purse in gravel. Ever.
